title: 107_s1541
content: The title of the act is the "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001". It also includes provisions regarding Federal-State agreements. Any State may enter into an agreement with the Secretary of Labor to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted regular benefits. The agreement can be terminated with a 30-day notice. The State agency will make payments of temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted all rights to regular compensation under State law and have no rights to compensation for a week under any other law. (c) Exhaustion of Benefits.--An individual is deemed to have exhausted their rights to regular compensation under a State law when they have no rights to compensation for a week under any other law, and are not receiving compensation under the unemployment compensation law of Canada. An individual exhausts their rights to regular compensation under a State law when no more payments can be made due to receiving all available compensation based on employment or wages during the base period. An individual exhausts their rights to regular compensation under a State law when no more payments can be made due to receiving all available compensation based on employment or wages during the base period or when their rights to such compensation have been terminated due to the expiration of the benefit year. Weekly benefit amounts for temporary emergency unemployment compensation are determined under any agreement. The weekly benefit amount for temporary emergency unemployment compensation is equal to the regular compensation payable under the State law for a week of total unemployment. The terms and conditions of the State law apply to the agreement. The weekly benefit amount for temporary emergency unemployment compensation is equal to the regular compensation payable under the State law for a week of total unemployment. The terms and conditions of the State law apply to claims for temporary emergency unemployment compensation and its payment, except where inconsistent with the provisions of this title or with the regulations of the Secretary. The maximum amount of temporary emergency unemployment compensation payable to an individual shall not exceed the amount established in their account. The Governor of a State can elect to trigger off an extended compensation period to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted their regular compensation rights under State law. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION ACCOUNT. The State will establish temporary emergency unemployment compensation accounts for eligible individuals, with the amount in the account being 13 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount for the benefit year. The State will establish temporary emergency unemployment compensation accounts for eligible individuals, with the amount in the account being 13 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount for the benefit year. The amount in the account shall be reduced by any extended compensation received under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. The individual's temporary emergency unemployment compensation account will be reduced by any extended compensation received under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. The weekly benefit amount is based on the regular compensation payable for total unemployment. Payments to states with agreements for temporary emergency unemployment compensation. Payments to states with agreements for temporary emergency unemployment compensation. States that have entered into an agreement will receive 100 percent of the temporary emergency unemployment compensation paid to individuals. No payment will be made if the state is entitled to reimbursement under any other federal law. Sums payable to states under this section for compensation will not be made if the state is entitled to reimbursement under any other federal law. Payments to states with agreements will be made in advance or by reimbursement as determined. Sums payable to states with agreements under this title will be determined by the Secretary in advance or by reimbursement. The amounts paid will be based on the Secretary's estimates for each calendar month, adjusted for any discrepancies from prior months. The Secretary will determine the amounts payable to states under this title for each calendar month based on estimates, which may be adjusted for discrepancies from prior months. Estimates can be made using agreed-upon methods between the Secretary and the State agency. SEC. 5. FINANCING PROVISIONS. Funds in the extended unemployment compensation account shall be used for payments to States with agreements under this title. The Secretary certifies sums payable to each State for payment by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Secretary certifies sums payable to each State for payment by the Secretary of the Treasury from the extended unemployment compensation account to the State's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. Funds are appropriated to assist States as provided in title III of the Social Security Act. Transfers are made from the extended unemployment compensation account to the State's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. The extended unemployment compensation account transfers funds to the State's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. Appropriations are made to assist States in covering administration costs of agreements under this title. Authorization of appropriations is provided for specific payments under this section. The Secretary estimates necessary funds from the Unemployment Trust Fund for payments under this section for compensation under chapter 85 of title 5, United States Code, and compensation based on services under section 3309(a)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Appropriated amounts do not need to be repaid. SEC. 6. FRAUD AND OVERPAYMENTS. If an individual knowingly makes a false statement or fails to disclose a material fact to receive unauthorized temporary emergency unemployment compensation, they will be ineligible for further benefits according to state laws on fraud in unemployment claims. Individuals who receive unauthorized temporary emergency unemployment compensation will be ineligible for further benefits according to state laws on fraud and may face prosecution under federal law. States will require repayment from individuals who received benefits they were not entitled to. Individuals who received unauthorized temporary emergency unemployment compensation may face prosecution under federal law and will be required to repay the amounts to the State agency if deemed ineligible. This title defines key terms related to compensation and benefits. SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY. This section outlines the scope of the regulations. SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY. An agreement under this Act applies to unemployment weeks starting after the agreement and ending within 18 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 9. TEMPORARY REDUCTION IN INTEREST RATE FOR STATE UNEMPLOYMENT FUND ADVANCES: During the 18-month period after the enactment of this Act, the interest rate on advances made to a State under the Social Security Act will be reduced from 10 percent to 5 percent.
